Class CollisionEvent

java.lang.Object
us.stomberg.solarsystemsim.physics.CollisionEvent
All Implemented Interfaces:
Comparable<CollisionEvent>
public class CollisionEvent extends Object implements Comparable<CollisionEvent>
The CollisionEvent class represents a collision between two celestial bodies in the simulation.

This class stores information about:

  • The two bodies involved in the collision
  • The time at which the collision occurs

CollisionEvent implements Comparable to allow sorting events chronologically in a priority queue, ensuring that collisions are processed in the correct temporal order during simulation.

When a collision occurs, the smaller body is merged into the larger one following conservation of mass and momentum principles. This models the physical process of celestial bodies combining after impact.

  • Constructor Details

    • CollisionEvent

      public CollisionEvent(Body a, Body b, double t)
      Creates a new collision event between two bodies at a specific time.

      The time parameter represents the relative time from the current simulation step when the collision will occur.

      Parameters:
      a - The first body involved in the collision
      b - The second body involved in the collision
      t - The relative time until the collision occurs

  • Method Details

    • processCollision

      public void processCollision(List<Body> bodies, TimeStep timeStep, Integrator integrator)
      Processes a collision between two celestial bodies.

      This method implements the physical effects of a collision by:

      • Determining which body is more massive (to be preserved)
      • Rolling back all bodies to the exact moment of collision
      • Calculating the new position through mass-weighted interpolation
      • Calculating the new velocity through conservation of momentum
      • Merging mass, density, and radius properties
      • Removing the consumed body from the simulation

      The collision follows conservation of mass and momentum principles, where the smaller body is consumed by the larger body.

      Parameters:
      bodies - The list of all bodies in the simulation
      timeStep - The current simulation time step
      integrator - The numerical integrator used for rolling back positions
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - If any of the parameters are null

    • getT

      public double getT()
      Returns the time until the collision occurs.

      This value represents the time interval from the current simulation step until the projected collision will take place.

      Returns:
      The relative time until collision occurs

    • equals

      public boolean equals(Object o)
      Determines whether this collision event is equal to another object.

      Two collision events are considered equal if they involve the same two bodies, regardless of their order. This implementation supports the proper functioning of hash-based collections.

      The collision time is not considered for equality since multiple potential collisions between the same bodies should be treated as equivalent events.

      Overrides:
      equals in class Object
      Parameters:
      o - The object to compare with this collision event
      Returns:
      true if the objects are equal, false otherwise

    • compareTo

      public int compareTo(CollisionEvent other)
      Compares this collision event with another based on their occurrence times.

      This method allows collision events to be sorted chronologically in priority queues or other ordered collections, ensuring that events are processed in the correct temporal sequence during simulation.

      Events with earlier occurrence times are considered "less than" those with later times.

      Specified by:
      compareTo in interface Comparable<CollisionEvent>
      Parameters:
      other - The collision event to compare with this one
      Returns:
      A negative integer if this event occurs before the other, zero if they occur simultaneously, or a positive integer if this event occurs after the other
